HRT100.name: Horticulture: Plants and People
HRT100.restrictions: Not open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Horticulture.

HRT102.name: Plants for Food, Fun, and Profit
HRT102.semester: Fall of every year, Summer of every year
HRT102.description: Introduction to the science and art of horticulture including plant breeding, ornamental plant and food production (organic and traditional), postharvest handling, horticultural industries and landscaping. Educate consumers about horticultural plants, products, and their relationship to environment.

HRT109.name: Introduction to Applied Plant Science
HRT109.description: Plant growth and development. Interrelationship between cultural practice and plant performance. Plant classification, plant physiology and metabolism.
HRT109.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

HRT111.name: Landscape Design
HRT111.description: Functional uses of the landscape, landscape design process, drafting and graphic representation, plant selection and use, planting design principles, construction materials and specifications. Offered first ten weeks of semester.

HRT124.name: Introduction to Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
HRT124.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRT124.description: Contemporary research and movements involving agricultural and food system sustainability. Socio-cultural factors influencing food and agriculture.
HRT124.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT135.name: Crop Scouting and Investigation
HRT135.description: Crop scouting and agricultural clientele interactions for improved crop management. Offered first ten weeks of semester.
HRT135.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT203.name: Introduction to Horticulture
HRT203.description: Concepts and practices of horticulture. Crop selection and management, factors affecting plant growth and development, and plant identification. Field trip required.

HRT204.name: Plant Propagation and Use
HRT204.description: Asexual and sexual propagation. Genetic variation and plant selection/breeding. Plant production, use and plant identification. Field trip required.

HRT205.name: Plant Mineral Nutrition
HRT205.description: Mineral elements required by plants. Essential elements, effect of soil and potting media on nutrient availability, absorption and function in plant physiology, and nutrient deficiency and toxicity symptoms. Methods of monitoring and managing plant nutrient levels. Class meets first five weeks of semester.

HRT206.name: Training and Pruning Plants
HRT206.description: Principles and techniques of pruning for landscape and nursery ornamentals, Christmas tree production, tree fruits, and small fruits. Pruning practices, equipment, and basic large tree care techniques. Class meets last five weeks of the semester.

HRT207.name: Horticulture Career Development
HRT207.description: Internship preparation and identification of employment opportunities. Career goal establishment, resume construction, correspondence development, personal budgeting, interview skills and strategies.

HRT211.name: Landscape Plants I
HRT211.description: Identification, adaptation, and evaluation of shade trees, narrow-leaved evergreens, shrubs, woody vines, herbs, ornamental grasses, and herbaceous perennials.
HRT211.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT212.name: Landscape Plants II
HRT212.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRT212.description: Identification, adaptation, and evaluation of flowering trees and shrubs, evergreen trees and shrubs, ground covers and bulbs.
HRT212.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT213.name: Landscape Maintenance
HRT213.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of odd years
HRT213.description: Ornamental plant management. Plant growth and development related to pruning, fertilization, irrigation, weed control, transplanting; development of landscape management specifications; integrated plant management and plant health care programs.
HRT213.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT213L.name: Landscape Maintenance Field Laboratory
HRT213L.description: Landscape maintenance. Site analysis. Pruning woody plants, transplanting by hand and mechanical tree spade, and planting techniques for ornamentals. Herbaceous perennial care, cutting back, dividing. Scouting as a component of integrated pest management and plant health care programs.
HRT213L.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT214.name: Landscape and Turfgrass Business Operations
HRT214.description: Organizing, marketing, and directing a business enterprise within the turf and landscape industry. Project estimating, bidding, payroll, equipment, and accounting. Offered first ten weeks of semester.
HRT214.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT218.name: Irrigation Systems for Horticulture
HRT218.description: Irrigation design, installation, maintenance, hydraulics, equipment and component selection, pumps, troubleshooting, best management practices, water quality and conservation.
HRT218.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT218L.name: Irrigation Systems for Horticulture Laboratory
HRT218L.description: Irrigation design, installation, maintenance, controller programming, assembly of equipment and components, electrical and hydraulic troubleshooting.
HRT218L.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT219.name: Landscape Computer Aided Design
HRT219.description: Computer Aided Design (CAD) for landscape design. Calculations, take offs, perspective drawings using AutoCAD software. Offered first ten weeks of semester.

HRT220.name: Annual and Aquatic Landscape Plants
HRT220.description: Identification and evaluation of annuals, biennials and aquatic plants used in landscapes and for other horticultural purposes.
HRT220.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT221.name: Greenhouse Structures and Management
HRT221.description: Planning and operation of a commercial greenhouse. Structures, coverings, heating, cooling, ventilation, irrigation, fertilization, root media, and pest control.

HRT224.name: Sustainable Farm and Food Systems Field Studies
HRT224.description: Field visits to farm and food system operations that utilize sustainable practices in Michigan. Offered first half of semester.
HRT224.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or agricultural technology students.

HRT231.name: Clerkship in Grape Harvesting and Processing
HRT231.description: Hands-on skills in the management of grape harvest and processing; winery and cellar operations. Course meets on-farm. Field trips required.
HRT231.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT232.name: Principles of Viticulture
HRT232.description: Grapevine physiology, grape production, cultural practices and vineyard management. Field trip required.
HRT232.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT233.name: Field Practices of Viticulture
HRT233.description: Cool climate grape production and vineyard management. Field trips required.
HRT233.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT234.name: Current Issues in Viticulture and Enology
HRT234.description: Grape, juice, and wine production. Current and new technologies. Wine sales and marketing. Vineyard and winery establishment and management. Presentations and discussions by MSU faculty and Michigan grape and wine industry professionals.
HRT234.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT242.name: Passive Solar Greenhouses for Protected Cultivation
HRT242.description: Season extension and year-round vegetable, herb, flower, and fruit production in unheated, low cost passive solar greenhouses. Marketing options, site selection, site preparation, structures, and organic crop management methods. Field trip required.
HRT242.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT243.name: Organic Transplant Production
HRT243.description: Seed ordering. Seed storage and seed germination. Vegetative propagation. Growing containers. Organic root media. Fertility, light, and temperature. Plant health. Hardening off. Considerations for organic certification. Field trip required.

HRT251.name: Organic Farming Principles and Practices
HRT251.description: History and principles of organic farming. Farms as ecological systems. Certification process and agencies. Organic matter management, the soil food web, and nutrient availability. Biodiversity, crop rotations, plant competition, ground cover, and plant health. Integrating crops and animals. Organic animal husbandry. Field trip required.

HRT253.name: Compost Production and Use
HRT253.description: Process and methods of composting, maturity and quality analysis, and use of compost products at home and farm scale. Field trip required.
HRT253.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

HRT290.name: Independent Study in Horticulture
HRT290.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT290.description: A planned learning experience developed by the student in cooperation with a faculty member.
HRT290.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

HRT310.name: Nursery Management
HRT310.description: Management and cultural practices of field and container grown nursery operations. Site selection and development, financing, legal restrictions, personnel management, production practices, nutrition, irrigation, weed and pest control, modification of plant growth, storage, shipping, and marketing. Field trip required.

HRT311.name: Landscape Design and Management Specifications
HRT311.description: Landscape design techniques, spatial organization, plant selection, plant and site interaction. Relationship between design, construction and maintenance. Preparation of planting and maintenance specifications.

HRT323.name: Floriculture Production: Herbaceous Perennials and Annuals
HRT323.description: Commercial greenhouse and outdoor production of herbaceous perennials, annuals, and other plants typically sold in retail nurseries for outdoor gardens. Plant identification, propagation, production, scheduling, and finishing procedures based on specific plant growth requirements. Plant selection, marketing, and retailing issues.
HRT323.prerequisite: HRT 203 and (HRT 204 or concurrently) and HRT 221

HRT332.name: Tree Fruit Production and Management
HRT332.description: Commercial apple, cherry, peach, and pear production. Cultural practices to manipulate growth and development and optimize fruit yields and quality. Field trips required.

HRT336.name: Viticulture and Berry Production
HRT336.description: Commercial production of grapes, blueberries, strawberries, raspberries, blackberries, cranberries and minor fruit. Physiology, growth and development of these species. Cultural practices used to optimize fruit yields and quality. Field trip required.

HRT341.name: Vegetable Production and Management
HRT341.description: Field production of vegetable crops. Marketing systems, tillage practices, field establishment, cultural management, pest management, harvesting, and postharvest handling and storage.

HRT361.name: Applied Plant Physiology
HRT361.description: Whole plant physiological and growth responses of plants to light, temperature, and gases during commercial plant production. Coordination and management of growth for optimum production and quality.

HRT362.name: Applied Crop Improvement
HRT362.description: History of plant improvement. Basic genetic principles of crop breeding and biotechnology. Class meets weeks 6 to 10 of the semester.

HRT401.name: Advanced Horticultural Crop Physiology
HRT401.description: Physiological and flowering responses of horticultural crop plants to environmental variables. Adaptive responses of plants to environmental stress Management of these factors for optimum production.
HRT401.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

HRT403.name: Handling and Storage of Horticultural Crops
HRT403.description: Biological principles involved in quality maintenance of horticultural products. Control of deterioration during harvesting, handling, transport, and storage.
HRT403.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

HRT404.name: Horticulture Management (W)
HRT404.description: Integration of management, economic, marketing, and horticultural production principles to develop personnel, financial, and resource strategies. Horticultural business plan development in a team situation. Effects of business decisions on people and profits.
HRT404.prerequisite: (HRT 203) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
HRT404.restrictions: Open to seniors in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.

HRT405.name: Sustainable Practices for Horticultural Food Crop Production
HRT405.description: Effects of horticultural practices on ecosystem services, integrated efficiency across perennial and annual food crop production systems. Impact of crops on the land and biodiversity. Management decision-making. Global forces impacting sustainability.

HRT407.name: Horticulture Marketing
HRT407.description: Demographic and purchase trends of perishable horticultural commodities including landscape and floral crops, and fruits and vegetables. Market segmentation and product targeting, distribution, branding and packaging, and advertising and promotion. Services as a critical component of strategic business planning.
HRT407.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources.

HRT411.name: Landscape Contract Management
HRT411.description: Management of landscape construction and maintenance operations. Working drawing, contracts, bonds, and insurance. Estimating and bidding procedures. Installation techniques for hardscapes and plant material.

HRT415.name: Natural Landscapes, Native Plants and Landscape Restoration
HRT415.description: Natural landscapes, native plants and landscape restoration options for natural and built environments. Planning and design approaches, site engineering, construction practices, and management guidelines. Case studies, regulatory policies, contract services, resources and issues. Field trip required.
HRT415.prerequisite: HRT 211 or HRT 212 or BS 162 or LB 144

HRT417.name: Sustainable Sites and Environmental Landscape Practices
HRT417.description: Sustainable sites and environmental landscape practices integrated into the built environment. Planning and design approaches, site engineering, construction practices, and management guidelines. Case studies, specifications, certification programs.

HRT424.name: Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems: Integration and Synthesis
HRT424.description: Biogeochemical and socio-economic aspects of food, fiber, and fuel production. Environmental impacts and social context. Experiential learning projects.
HRT424.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HRT430.name: Exploring Wines and Vines
HRT430.description: Consumer-oriented study of wine history, production methods, climatic influences, cultural impacts, social responsibility, and economic impact of wine industry as part of modern agriculture. Sensory evaluation and its relationship to food pairings.

HRT441.name: Plant Breeding and Biotechnology
HRT441.description: Plant improvement by genetic manipulation. History of plant breeding. Traditional and biotechnological means of improving plant cultivars by genetic manipulation. Importance of plant breeding to our food system, economy, and environment.

HRT451.name: Biotechnology Applications for Plant Breeding and Genetics
HRT451.description: Principles, concepts, and techniques of agricultural plant biotechnology. Recombinant DNA technology, plant molecular biology and transformation in relation to plant improvement.
HRT451.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HRT460.name: Green Roofs and Walls
HRT460.description: Green roof and wall design and installation practices including plant species and substrates. Environmental impact, ecosystem services, integration with other environmental practices. Influence of economics, public policy, and industry organizations on the implementation of green roofs on a wide scale. Multidisciplinary nature of planning and implementation of successful green roof and wall projects.
HRT460.prerequisite: HRT 203 or FW 101 or GEO 206 or PDC 120 or EGR 100
HRT460.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HRT461.name: Seminar in Plant, Animal and Microbial Biotechnology
HRT461.description: Current applications of plant, animal and microbial biotechnology in agriculture and related industries. Technologies under development and factors associated with moving from laboratory to product development. Field trips required.
HRT461.prerequisite: (ANS 425 or concurrently) or (BE 360 or concurrently) or (CSS 451 or concurrently) or (MMG 445 or concurrently)

HRT475.name: International Studies in Horticulture
HRT475.semester: Spring of odd years, Summer of every year
HRT475.description: Study and travel experience emphasizing contemporary problems, issues, and trends in horticulture.

HRT477.name: Pesticides in Pest Management
HRT477.description: Chemistry, modes of action, product development and regulation of pesticides. Environmental and social aspects of pesticide use.
HRT477.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

HRT486.name: Biotechnology in Agriculture: Applications and Ethical Issues
HRT486.description: Current and future roles of biotechnology in agriculture
HRT486.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

HRT490.name: Independent Study
HRT490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT490.description: Independent study of horticulture on a field, laboratory, or library research program of special interest to the student.

HRT491.name: Selected Topics in Horticulture
HRT491.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRT491.description: Selected topics in horticulture of current interest and importance.
HRT491.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

HRT492.name: Undergraduate Research
HRT492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT492.description: Mentored field or laboratory research experience.

HRT493.name: Professional Internship in Horticulture
HRT493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT493.description: Professional career-related work experience supervised by a professional horticulturist.
HRT493.restrictions: Open to seniors. Approval of department; application required. A student may earn a maximum of 6 credits in all enrollments for any or all of these courses

HRT812.name: Laboratory Research Techniques
HRT812.description: Demonstration and experience using various research techniques.
HRT812.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Horticulture.

HRT816.name: Environmental Design Theory
HRT816.description: Differences between normative theories, scientific theories, models, and constructs. Exploration of normative theories related to thesis or practicum.

HRT817.name: Environmental Design Studio
HRT817.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRT817.description: Development of a student-selected environmental design project in a collaborative setting.

HRT819.name: Advanced Plant Breeding
HRT819.description: Genetic expectations resulting from breeding strategies with cross- and self-pollinated crop plants. Germplasm collections, mapping populations, and modifications of reproductive biology useful for crop improvement.

HRT820.name: Plant Reproductive Biology and Polyploidy
HRT820.description: Genetic processes underlying variations in plant reproductive biology and polyploidy. Utilization of these characteristics in plant breeding.

HRT840.name: Agroforestry Systems
HRT840.description: Agroforestry systems with a local and global perspectives, abbreviate biological and chemical processes in agroforestry ecosystems, effects and potential of agroforestry on forest dependent communities, climate change and ecosystem sustainability. Field trips required.

HRT853.name: Plant Mineral Nutrition
HRT853.description: Inorganic ion transport in plant cells and tissues. Physiological responses and adaptation to problem soils. Genetic diversity in nutrient uptake and use by plants. Physiological roles of elemental nutrients in crop growth.

HRT863.name: Environmental Plant Physiology
HRT863.description: Interaction of plant and environment. Photobiology, thermophysiology, and plant-water relations.

HRT865.name: Plant Growth and Development
HRT865.description: Genetics and molecular biology of development in higher plants as influenced by genes and environment. Biosynthesis, action and signal transduction of phytohormones and other signaling molecules. Initiation, formation and patterning of plant organs and cell types. Genetic mechanisms underlying developmental diversity.

HRT883.name: Environmental Design Seminar
HRT883.description: Examination of the breadth of environmental design projects. Literature review of focused projects. Development of practicum or thesis proposals.
HRT883.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Horticulture or in the School of Planning, Design and Construction.

HRT890.name: Independent Study
HRT890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT890.description: Individual study of problems of special interest.

HRT891A.name: Selected Topics in Horticulture
HRT891A.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT891A.description: Horticultural science topics of current interest and importance.
HRT891A.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Horticulture. Approval of department.

HRT891B.name: Selected Topics in Plant Breeding and Genetics
HRT891B.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT891B.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Plant Breeding and Genetics major or Genetics major. Approval of department.

HRT892.name: Plant Breeding and Genetics Seminar
HRT892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT892.description: Experience in review, organization, oral presentation, and analysis of research.

HRT894.name: Horticulture Seminar
HRT894.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
HRT894.description: Experience in review, organization, oral presentation and analysis of research.

HRT898.name: Master's Research
HRT898.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

HRT899.name: Master's Thesis Research
HRT899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT899.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Horticulture.

HRT941.name: Quantitative Genetics in Plant Breeding
HRT941.description: Theoretical and genetic basis of statistical analysis of quantitative traits using genetic markers. Computational tools for the study of quantitative traits.

HRT999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
HRT999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
HRT999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the Department of Horticulture.
